title: Privacy, Consent, and AI Surveillance
subtitle: Balancing Safety, Convenience, and Human Autonomy in the Digital Age
description: Explore the complex ethical landscape where AI-powered surveillance systems promise enhanced safety and convenience while challenging fundamental privacy rights and human autonomy.
learningObjectives: Understand the evolution and limitations of traditional consent models in AI surveillance
Analyze the power dynamics between institutions and individuals in data collection
Evaluate different approaches to protecting privacy while enabling beneficial AI applications
Develop frameworks for ethical surveillance that respect human dignity and autonomy
Create strategies for promoting informed consent and data literacy

Privacy Literacy.exemplary: Demonstrates sophisticated understanding of privacy concepts, data flows, and surveillance technologies
Privacy Literacy.proficient: Shows solid grasp of privacy issues and their implications
Privacy Literacy.developing: Basic understanding of privacy concepts with limited technical depth
Privacy Literacy.novice: Minimal comprehension of privacy issues and surveillance systems

Ethical Analysis.exemplary: Provides nuanced ethical analysis that balances multiple competing values and interests
Ethical Analysis.proficient: Good ethical reasoning with consideration of key stakeholder perspectives
Ethical Analysis.developing: Basic ethical analysis with limited consideration of complexity
Ethical Analysis.novice: Struggles to identify or analyze ethical dimensions of surveillance

System Design Thinking.exemplary: Creates innovative and practical solutions that effectively balance privacy and functionality
System Design Thinking.proficient: Develops good design solutions with clear privacy considerations
System Design Thinking.developing: Basic design thinking with limited integration of privacy principles
System Design Thinking.novice: Struggles to design systems that protect privacy while delivering benefits

Stakeholder Awareness.exemplary: Expertly considers diverse perspectives and power dynamics with sophisticated analysis
Stakeholder Awareness.proficient: Good understanding of different stakeholder needs and concerns
Stakeholder Awareness.developing: Basic awareness of stakeholder perspectives with surface-level analysis
Stakeholder Awareness.novice: Limited ability to consider multiple perspectives or understand power dynamics

preparationGuide.overview: This lab addresses one of the most pressing ethical challenges of our time: how to harness the benefits of AI surveillance technologies while protecting fundamental privacy rights and human autonomy.
keyFocusAreas: Evolution and limitations of consent in digital surveillance contexts
Power dynamics between institutions and individuals in data collection
Differential impacts of surveillance on various communities
Technical and policy approaches to privacy-preserving AI
commonMisconceptions: Privacy is only important for people who have something to hide
Individual consent is sufficient to address all surveillance ethics issues
There's always a clear trade-off between security and privacy

discussionPrompts: How do cultural differences influence expectations about privacy and surveillance?
What constitutes meaningful consent in contexts where opting out isn't really possible?
How should society balance collective benefits against individual privacy rights?
What role should vulnerable populations play in designing surveillance systems that affect them?
extensionActivities: Research privacy laws and regulations in different countries and their effectiveness
Interview community members about their experiences with surveillance technologies
Create public education materials about digital privacy and surveillance
Design privacy-preserving alternatives to existing surveillance systems

vocabulary.definition: Agreement to surveillance based on full understanding of what data is collected and how it's used
Building privacy protection into systems from the ground up rather than adding it later
Collecting only the minimum data necessary to achieve a specific purpose
Economic model based on extracting and analyzing personal data for commercial purposes
Technical approach that adds noise to data to protect individual privacy while enabling analysis

crossCurricular.socialStudies: Exploring historical examples of surveillance and their impacts on society
crossCurricular.law: Understanding legal frameworks for privacy protection and surveillance regulation
crossCurricular.technology: Learning about technical approaches to privacy-preserving data analysis
crossCurricular.psychology: Understanding the psychological impacts of surveillance on behavior and wellbeing
crossCurricular.publicPolicy: Analyzing policy responses to surveillance technologies and their effectiveness

reflectionQuestions: How has this lab changed your awareness of surveillance in your daily life?
What trade-offs are you willing to make between convenience/safety and privacy?
How do you think surveillance affects different communities in your area?
What actions can you take to promote ethical surveillance practices in your community?
How might future generations view our current approaches to privacy and surveillance?
